On Tue, 8 Apr 2003, Miles Sabin wrote:

> S. Alexander Jacobson wrote,
> > The transition to OOP resulted in new programming languages
> > specifically designed to support that style of programming.  Is anyone
> > working on a ReST Oriented Programming Environments?
> 
> Not as such to the best of my knowledge.
> 
> But if you squint really hard, you might notice that REST has an awful 
> lot in common with the programming model implicit in the pi-calculus 
> ... the key point is to think of a URI in REST corresponding to the 
> name of a communication channel in pi.

Interesting paper on pi-calculus. (I wonder if an arc could be a channel?)

http://www.dcs.ed.ac.uk/home/fhlt/docs/project.pdf

<quote>The models are based on a new mathematical structure which 
we call pi- forests. We build an abstract machine which has 
these structures as machine states, almost as if we are 
presenting an implementation</quote>

> I think the most interesting aspect of the comparison is that REST's 
> most powerful idiom (passing continuation/capability URIs in 
> request/response entities) carries over directly to pi (names of 
> channels can be passed over channels).
> 
> There are a few experimental programming languages modelled on pi which 
> you might enjoy playing with. They might also be a source of 
> inspiration for anyone interested in putting together a full-blown REST 
> toolkit. PICT and Nomadic PICT are probably the most interesting ... 
> implementations for Linux available here,
> 
>   http://lsewww.epfl.ch/~pawel/nomadicpict.html

> Cheers,
>
